questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Table 1 indicates the presence or absence of 6 traits in 7 dinosaur genera (genera is the plural of genus).

Figure 1 is a cladogram (a diagram showing evolutionary relationships) for these dinosaur genera based on the 6 traits in Table 1. Figure 1 also includes 6 dinosaurs (A-F) at 6 nodes (branch points).The dinosaur at each node represents the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of the dinosaur genera extending upward from that node. Each MRCA had all traits that were shared by all of the genera extending upward from it.


Table 1 and Figure 1 adapted from Neil A. Campbell, Biology, 4th ed. @1996 by The Benjamin/Cummings Publishing Company, lnc.

Table 2 indicates when each of the 7 dinosaur genera in Table 1 existed.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
When fossil fuels are burned, sulfur (S) enters the air as sulfur dioxide gas (SO2), which is then converted to sulfuric acid (H2SO4) :

1) 2SO2 + O2 →2 SO3
2) SO3 + H2O → H2SO4

Rain containing the H2SO4 then deposits the sulfur into lakes.

Figure 1 shows data on the average rate of sulfur deposition in numerous lakes throughout Ontario, Canada. Figure 2 shows, for Zones 1-5 in Figure 1, the average SO42- concentration (which is a measure of deposited H2SO4), the average alkalinity (the average concentration of substances in lake water that neutralize acidity), and the average pH in lake waters versus the average rate of sulfur deposition.


Figures adapted from B. P. Neary and P. J. Dillon, "Effects of Sulfur Deposition on Lake-Water Chemistry in Ontario, Canada." ©1988 by Macmillan Journals, Ltd.
questions.question: 6. Based on the data in Figure 2, as the average rate of sulfur deposition increased, the average lake water pH:

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
Jalapeño pepper slices can be preserved by canning, in which they are placed in jars, covered with a brine (a solution of dissolved salts in water), heated, and then sealed. Over time, the texture of canned jalapeño slices can soften, which makes them less desirable to consumers. Chemists studied how preheating the jalapeño slices in water or in a brine prior to canning affects their texture over time.

Experiment 1
Jalapeños of identical freshness were cut into 5 mm thick slices and divided into 500 g samples. Samples were covered with water and preheated at 50°C for different periods of time and then drained. These samples, and a sample that received no preheating treatment, were each canned in the same manner. After 1 month (mo) of storage at 23°℃, the samples were tested with a texture press, which evaluates texture by determining the minimum force (in newtons, N) needed to completely cut through a specified thickness of pepper slices. The results are shown in Figure 1.


Experiment 2
Samples were preheated at 50°C for 60 min in water, or in 1 of 2 brines, or given no preheating treatment. Then, as in Experiment 1, they were drained, canned, and evaluated for texture after 1 mo of storage at 23°C (see Table 1).


Experiment 3
Samples were preheated in Brine B at 50°C for 60 min, then drained and canned as in Experiment 1. The texture of the slices was evaluated after different storage times at 23°C. The procedure was repeated with a sample that had no preheating treatment (see Figure 2).


Figures and table adapted from L. R. Howard, P. Burma, and A. B. Wagner, "Firmness and Cell Wall Characteristics of Pasteurized Jalapeño Pepper Rings as Affected by Preheating and Storage." @1997 by the Institute of Food Technologists.
questions.question: 11. According to the results of Experiment 1, as the preheating time increased from 0 min to 60 min, the measured texture of the jalapeño samples increased, then:

questions.question: 12.  A company determined that it was only cost effective to preheat jalapeño slices for 45 min or less at 50℃ in water. Based on the results of Experiment 1, what preheating time should the company use to best maintain slices at their maximum firmness?

questions.question: 15.  According to the results of Experiment 2, the measured texture of preheated jalapeño samples after 1 mo of storage increased as the:

choices.A: preheating time for each sample increased.
choices.B: preheating time for each sample decreased.
choices.C: concentration of dissolved salts in the preheating solutions increased.
choices.D: concentration of dissolved salts in the preheating solutions decreased.

questions.question: 16.  A chemist claimed that when jalapeño slices are processed according to the procedure in Experiment 3 (preheated in Brine B), they will be softest at 2 mo of storage at 23°C. Do the results support her claim?

choices.A: Yes; the softest texture was measured at 2 mo of storage.
choices.B: No; the softest texture was measured at 5 mo of storage.
choices.C: Yes; the firmest texture was measured at 2 mo of storage.
choices.D: No; the firmest texture was measured at 5 mo of storage.

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
One type of torsion pendulum consists of a wire tied to a rod with a disk on each end. The pendulum is suspended from a support (see Figure 1).


The rod is turned, twisting the wire, and then released, causing the rod and disks to oscillate (twist back and forth) in a horizontal arc, as shown in the top views in Figure 2.


The period is the time required for the rod to complete 1 round trip. Tables 1-3 give the periods of torsion pendulums made with identical wires and various disk masses, rod masses, and rod lengths.
questions.question: 17. Based on the data in Table 3, which of the following bar graphs best represents the periods of the torsion pendulums having a rod mass of 30 g, a rod length of 10 cm, and a mass per disk of 1 g, 2 g, or 3 g?

questions.question: 21.  Consider the torsion pendulum with a 1 g disk on each end, a rod mass of 20 g, and a rod length of 5 cm. Based on the data in the 3 tables, making which of the following changes to the pendulum produced the greatest amount of change in the period of the pendulum?

choices.A: Replacing the rod with one having the same length and a mass of 10 g
choices.B: Replacing the rod with one having the same mass and a length of 15 cm
choices.C: Replacing each 1 g disk with a 2 g disk
choices.D: Replacing each 1 g disk with a 3 g disk

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Soil sealing occurs when rain breaks exposed soil particles into smaller pieces, which then fill empty spaces in the soil. This process decreases the rate at which water infiltrates (soaks into) the soil. Three studies investigated factors affecting soil sealing.

Study 1
Samples from the top 5 cm of 2 different soils (A and B) were analyzed for their relative proportion of sand, silt, and clay. The results are shown in Table 1.

Srudy 2
Dried samples of each of the 2 soils were placed in separate trays that had perforated bottoms. The trays were put into shallow water to saturate each soil and then were allowed to drain. The trays were then placed on a 5% slope and subjected to simulated rain from a fall height (distance from the rain source to the tray) of 0.4 m at a constant rate of 40 mm/hr (see Figure 1) . The runoff (amount of water that ran off the soil's surface) was measured for each tray every 6 minutes for 2 hours. The amount of rain that infiltrated each soil during each 6-minute period was calculated by subtracting runoff from rainfall.

This procedure was repeated twice, using simulated rain from 2 other fall heights. Each repeat used fresh samples of both soils prepared as described above. The calculated infiltration rates for each 6-minute period are shown in Figure 2 for Soil A and Figure 3 for Soil B.

Srudy 3
The impact velocity and kinetic energy per kg of rain for the simulated rain falling from the 3 heights used in Study 2 were calculated. The results are shown in Table 2.


Tables and figures adapted from I. Betzalel et al., "Water Drop Energy and Soil Seal Properties." @1995 by Williams and Wilkins.
questions.question: 22. Which of the following statements best describes the relative sand contents of the 2 soils as shown by the results of Study 1?

choices.A: Soil B's sand content is about half that of Soil A.
choices.B: Soil B's sand content is about twice that of Soil A.
choices.C: Soil B's sand content is about 3 times that of Soil A.
choices.D: Soil B's sand content is about the same as that of Soil A.

Srudy 3

Tables and figures adapted from I. Betzalel et al., "Water Drop Energy and Soil Seal Properties." @1995 by Williams and Wilkins.
questions.question: 23.  In Study 2, the trays were placed on a 5% slope instead of being positioned horizontally so that:

choices.A: the rain could run off the soils.
choices.B: the rain would impact the soils at a velocity of 0 m/sec.
choices.C: the soils would have a much higher infiltration rate.
choices.D: the soils would stay in the trays.

questions.question: 24.  Based on the description of Study 2, which of the following formulas was used to calculate the infiltration rates?

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Soil sealing occurs when rain breaks exposed soil particles into smaller pieces, which then fill empty spaces in the soil. This process decreases the rate at which water infiltrates (soaks into) the soil. Three studies investigated factors affecting soil sealing.

Study 1
Samples from the top 5 cm of 2 different soils (A and B) were analyzed for their relative proportion of sand, silt, and clay. The results are shown in Table 1.

Srudy 2
Dried samples of each of the 2 soils were placed in separate trays that had perforated bottoms. The trays were put into shallow water to saturate each soil and then were allowed to drain. The trays were then placed on a 5% slope and subjected to simulated rain from a fall height (distance from the rain source to the tray) of 0.4 m at a constant rate of 40 mm/hr (see Figure 1) . The runoff (amount of water that ran off the soil's surface) was measured for each tray every 6 minutes for 2 hours. The amount of rain that infiltrated each soil during each 6-minute period was calculated by subtracting runoff from rainfall.

This procedure was repeated twice, using simulated rain from 2 other fall heights. Each repeat used fresh samples of both soils prepared as described above. The calculated infiltration rates for each 6-minute period are shown in Figure 2 for Soil A and Figure 3 for Soil B.

Srudy 3
The impact velocity and kinetic energy per kg of rain for the simulated rain falling from the 3 heights used in Study 2 were calculated. The results are shown in Table 2.


Tables and figures adapted from I. Betzalel et al., "Water Drop Energy and Soil Seal Properties." @1995 by Williams and Wilkins.
questions.question: 25. A gardener wants to lay down a new flower bed using either Soil A or Soil B. Based on the results of Study 2, to ensure the highest infiltration rate after watering for 1 hr, which soil should the gardener select and from which height should the flower bed be watered?    Soil         Height for watering (m)

questions.question: 27.  Which of the following statements about the relationship between the calculated infiltration rates for the 2 soils at 1 hr and the kinetic energy per kg of rain of the simulated rain is supported by the information from Study 2 and Study 3?

choices.A: As the kinetic energy per kg of rain increased, the calculated infiltration rate increased for both soils.
choices.B: As the kinetic energy per kg of rain increased, the calculated infiltration rate decreased for both soils.
choices.C: As the kinetic energy per kg of rain increased, the calculated infiltration rate remained constant for both soils.
choices.D: As the kinetic energy per kg of rain increased, the calculated infiltration rate increased for Soil A, but decreased for Soil B.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
DNA molecules contain a linear sequence of base pairs (2 nitrogenous bases bonded together). There are
2 kinds of base pairs. Different DNA molecules have different base-pair sequences.

A restriction enzyme (RE) can cut a DNA molecule at a specific base-pair sequence, producing shorter DNA fragments. Three studies were done with DNA and REs. (In the 3 studies, the action of each RE did not affect the action of any other RE, and each RE cuts DNA at a different sequence. )

Study 1
A series of trials were performed with 2 REs and a DNA molecule that was 100 base pairs (bp) in length. Table 1 shows the RE (s) used in each trial, the number of DNA fragments produced after the original DNA molecule was exposed to the RE (s), and the length of the DNA fragments.


Using this data, a map of the original DNA molecule was drawn to show the location of the RE cuts (see Figure 1).

Study 2
Study 1 was repeated with a different 100 bp DNA molecule, the 2 REs used in Study 1, and 4 additional REs. The results appear in Table 2.

Study 3
Study 2 was repeated with a 100 bp DNA molecule that partially overlaps with the DNA molecule used in Study 2 and includes the DNA sites that were cut by RE1 and RE4 in Study 2. Figure 2 shows a map of this molecule, indicating the location of the RE cuts.
questions.question: 28. In Study 1, how many base pairs separate the cuts made by RE1 and RE2?

questions.question: 33.  A researcher discovered that when the DNA molecule used in Study 3 is exposed to a seventh RE (RE7), a single cut is made that is 15 bp from the cut made by RE1 and 10 bp from the cut made by RE3. questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
All cells have a thin outer layer called the plasma membrane. This membrane separates the cell's cytoplasm from the surrounding environment (see Figure 1).


Two models of the structure of the plasma membrane are proposed.

Model 1
Phospholipids are the most abundant type of molecule in the plasma membrane. These molecules consist of hydrophobic (water-repelling) tails composed of hydrocarbons and a hydrophilic (water-attracting)head containing a phosphate group (see Figure 2).


The phospholipids orient themselves to form a bilayer, with the tails on the inside of the bilayer and the heads forming the outer surfaces of the bilayer. A single layer of proteins coats both the inner and outer surfaces of the plasma membrane, rigidly holding the phospholipids in place. Small, protein-coated pores in the phospholipid bilayer allow small water-soluble molecules to pass in and out of the cell (see Figure 3).

Model 2
Model 2 agrees with Model 1 about the abundance and orientation of phospholipids in the bilayer; however, the way proteins are distributed differs. Some proteins are located in the inner half of the plasma membrane, some in the outer half. Transmembrane proteins span from the outside of the cell through the bilayer to the inside of the cell.

The proteins are distributed unevenly, giving the plasma membrane a rough appearance (see Figure 4). Since the phospholipids are not held in place by a layer of proteins, the plasma membrane is highly fluid, allowing phospholipids and proteins to move within the plasma membrane.

Figures 3 and 4 adapted from William T. Keeton and James L. Gould, Biological Science, 4th ed. 1986 by W. W. Norton & Company, Inc.
questions.question: 34. When phospholipids and water are mixed together. spherical structures containing water form. Which of the following structures is most consistent with phospholipid orientation described in the passage?

questions.question: 35.  Which of the following findings, if made, about the structure of the plasma membrane would be inconsistent with both Models I and 2?

choices.A: The plasma membrane is primarily composed of proteins and phospholipids.
choices.B: The phospholipid molecules that make up the plasma membrane are entirely hydrophobic.
choices.C: Protein molecules are found on both the inner and outer surfaces of the plasma membrane.
choices.D: The structure of the plasma membrane allows some compounds to enter the cell.

questions.question: 36.  Assuming that Model 2 is correct, which of the following is the most likely reason that some researchers incorrectly proposed Model 1? The researchers:

choices.A: lacked a microscope powerful enough to see proteins found within the bilayer.
choices.B: failed to use the correct chemical tests needed to identify the presence of phospholipids.
choices.C: improperly handled the plasma membrane, causing the phospholipids to reverse orientation.
choices.D: failed to preserve the integrity of the plasma membrane, causing it to flip inside-out.

questions.question: 37.  According to Model 1, which of the following cellular activities would be most related to the structure of the plasma membrane?

choices.A: The storage of digestive enzymes in the cell's nucleus
choices.B: The movement of molecules from the nucleus to the cytoplasm
choices.C: The expulsion of waste from the cytoplasm to the outside of the cell

questions.question: 39.  Researchers discovered hydrophilic groups on the outer edge of the phospholipid bilayer in a plasma membrane. Which of the models is supported by this finding and why?

choices.A: Model 1 only; it asserts that hydrocarbons are found on the outer edge of the bilayer.
choices.B: Model 2 only; it asserts that proteins are found on the inside of the bilayer.
choices.C: Both Models | and 2; both models assert that hydrophilic tails are found on the outside of the bilayer.
choices.D: Both Models 1 and 2; both models assert that hydrophilic heads are found on the outside of the bilayer.
